translated: Commentary on the Compendium of the Great Vehicle, Fascicle 3
Composed by Bodhisattva Vasubandhu
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on Imperial Order
Why is the defilement of birth not established?
Because it is not associated with the time of linking the continuum.
The commentary says:
If one does not believe in the existence of the Älaya consciousness, the defilement of birth will also not be established. This will now be shown.
Because it is not associated with the time of linking the continuum means it is not associated with the attainment of one's own body.
The treatise says:

If there is one who, having died in this non-concentrated stage, is born, the defiled mental consciousness arises in the state of the intermediate existence and links the continuum of birth. This defiled mental consciousness ceases in the intermediate existence, and in the mother's womb, the consciousness and kalala come together again.
If the mental consciousness itself comes together with it, and having come together, relies on this consciousness in the mother's womb, the mental consciousness turns.
If so, then there should be two mental consciousnesses turning simultaneously in the mother's womb.

Also, it is unreasonable that the consciousness that is united with that [manas] is the nature of mental consciousness, because it is defiled, because there is no interruption of time, and because the object of mental consciousness cannot be obtained.

Even if the united consciousness is precisely mental consciousness, is this united mental consciousness precisely the consciousness that is the support of all seeds, or is the other mental consciousness that arises in dependence on this consciousness the one that is the support of all seeds?
If this united consciousness is the consciousness that is the support of all seeds, it is precisely the store consciousness, and you establish it as mental consciousness by means of a different name.

If the consciousness that is the support is the consciousness that is the support of all seeds, then the consciousness that is the cause, i.e., the support, is not the consciousness that is the support of all seeds, and the consciousness that is the result, i.e., that which is supported, is the consciousness that is the support of all seeds. This is unreasonable.
Therefore, this united consciousness is not mental consciousness but is the consciousness that is retribution, which is the consciousness that is the support of all seeds.
The commentary explains:
The stage that is not concentrated is precisely the realm of desire.
To die is to perish.
The defiled mental consciousness is the mental consciousness that accompanies the passions.

The phrase â€œthe continuity of rebirthâ€ refers to the appropriation of a body. This defiled mental consciousness has as its object the existence that is born and ceases in the intermediate state between death and rebirth.

The phrase â€œthe union of the consciousness with the semen and bloodâ€ means that the consciousness and the semen and blood are in the same place and are not separated. If the united consciousness is the mental consciousness, then the remaining mental consciousnesses would arise supported by it. In that case, two mental consciousnesses would occur simultaneously, namely, the mental consciousness that is the support of the union and the mental consciousness that is supported by it.
Also, it is not reasonable that the united consciousness is of the nature of mental consciousness.
Why is this?
Because it is defiled and because there is no interruption of the period of time.

This mental consciousness is defiled by the passions of craving, etc., and it is defiled because it is supported by the defiled manas and because it has as its object the existence that is born. It is defiled because it is supported by manas, and it is the support of the remaining mental consciousnesses.
In this state, the consciousness that is retribution of the fundamental consciousness is not defiled, because it is indeterminate.
This consciousness of synthesis is always without interruption, because it is the evolving consciousness that is the support of karmic predispositions.
Because the objects of the mental consciousness cannot be found, the objects of the mental consciousness are clearly found, that is, all dharmas.
This consciousness of synthesis does not have such a clearly evident object, and therefore it is not reasonable that this consciousness is the nature of mental consciousness.
The treatise states:
Next, after the linking of birth, if one departs from the consciousness that is retribution, the grasping of material organs is also unobtainable.
Because the remaining consciousnesses have separate supports, and because they are not firmly abiding, these material organs should not depart from consciousness.
The commentary explains:
After the linking of birth means having already obtained one's own body.
If one departs from the consciousness that is retribution means departing from the Älaya consciousness. The remaining consciousnesses have separate supports.
Because they are not firmly abiding means that the remaining six consciousnesses are in separate locations and are easily moved and transformed.

For example, visual consciousness has the eye as its special support. In the same way, the other consciousnesses, such as auditory consciousness, have the material organs such as the ears as their special supports.
In accordance with this principle, these consciousnesses should only be said to appropriate their own organs as support.

Also, these consciousnesses are easily moved and changed, and sometimes they do not exist. If they were apart from the Älaya consciousness, the organs such as the eyes would not be able to appropriate them as support and would then decay and perish.
The Treatise says,
If consciousness and name-and-form are mutually dependent, like two bundles of reeds supporting each other, this is not possible apart from the consciousness as retribution.
The Commentary explains:
Apart from the consciousness as retribution means that apart from the Älaya consciousness, this mutual dependence is not possible. This will now be demonstrated.
The World Honored One said,
Consciousness conditions name-and-form, and name-and-form conditions consciousness.
Here, consciousness conditions name means the four non-material aggregates in the six consciousnesses.
Consciousness conditions form means the kalala.
If you do not admit the existence of the Älaya consciousness, what do you take as the consciousness that is the condition for name-and-form?
Because, in dependence on name-and-form, consciousness evolves in a continuous series, moment after moment, without interruption.
The Treatise says that
if one excludes the consciousness that is retribution, the nutriment of consciousness is not possible for sentient beings who have already been born.
Why is this?
Because among the six forms of consciousness, one cannot find any one that is able to perform the function of nutriment for sentient beings in the three realms.
The Commentary explains:
This statement shows that the nutriment of consciousness is not possible.
As the World-Honored One said:
There are four kinds of nutriments: first, coarse nutriment; second, nutriment as contact; third, nutriment as volition; and fourth, nutriment as consciousness.
Among these, coarse nutriment is that which transforms, because it benefits the support by transforming.
Nutriment as contact is that which grasps objects, because by temporarily being able to see objects such as form, it benefits the arising of the support.
The food of volition is that which is able to hope for, because by hoping for it benefits the support. For example, although one sees water in the distance, one does not die of thirst.

The food of consciousness is that which is able to grasp and hold, because by grasping and holding the support remains for a long time. If it were not so, then it would quickly rot and decay like a corpse.
Therefore, it must be admitted that consciousness is also food, because it is able to act as a support and benefit.
Herein, the food of contact belongs to the group of the six consciousnesses. The food of volition belongs to the desirous mind. What other consciousness can be said to be food?

Moreover, if there is no mind, in sleep, fainting, or entering cessation, the group of the six consciousnesses ceases. What else remains that is able to grasp and hold the body, preventing it from rotting?
If one abandons the Älaya consciousness, the body would certainly rot.
The treatise says:
When one dies from this realm and is reborn in a realm of equipoise, the defiled mental consciousness that is not in equipoise forms the bond of rebirth and continues in a series.
This non-concentrated defiled mind is included in that stage. Apart from the consciousness as retribution, the substance of its seeds can definitely not be found.
The commentary says:
Thus, it has been explained that the continuation of rebirth in the non-concentrated stages cannot be established apart from the consciousness as retribution.
Just as in the concentrated stages, it also cannot be established. This will now be shown.

That is to say, in this place, the continuation of rebirth is due to the defiled consciousness. In the concentrated stages, the continuation of rebirth is due to the non-concentrated defiled mental consciousness.ğŸ”½As for the defiled, it is defiled by the passions of that stage.
The passions of that stage refer to those that partake of the flavor of concentration, and so forth.
This defiled mind is in the indeterminate stage.
When falling from the indeterminate stage, after falling from there, how can the mind of that stage appear?
If it does not appear, how can there be the continuation of rebirth?

For this reason, it is definitely necessary to admit that the Älaya consciousness has existed since beginningless time, and that this mind is perfumed by the land, and that the active forms of mind appear because of this perfuming. It is because of this mind that there is rebirth and the continuity of consciousness.
The treatise states:

Next, if one is born in the formless realm and is devoid of the consciousness that is retribution containing all the seeds, then defiled and good minds would be without seeds, and defiled and good minds would be without a support.
The commentary explains:
Born in the formless realm refers to those who have already been liberated from the form realm.
Defiled and good minds refers to those that savor and enjoy samÄdhi.
Would be without seeds means they would be without a cause.
Would be without a support means they would be without a basis.
There is another interpretation: if these two minds are without seeds, from what do they arise?
If they are without a support, on what do they depend in order to occur?
Because it is grasped by the Älaya consciousness, arises from its own seeds, and serves as the support for the dependent.
The treatise says:
Moreover, if a supramundane mind is present in that realm, the other worldly minds would all cease, and at that time one would be separated from that destiny.
The commentary says:
If a supramundane mind is present in that realm, the other worldly minds would all cease at that time.
In this way, that destiny would be permanently severed, and one would naturally realize nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder without effort.
Since this is not the case, one should not deny the existence of the Älaya consciousness.
The treatise says:
If one is born in the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception or the sphere of nothingness, and a supramundane mind is present, then one would be separated from both destinies.

This supramundane consciousness does not take the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception as its support, nor should it take the base of nothingness as its support, nor is it supported by nirvÄá¹‡a.
The commentary explains:

If one is born in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, sometimes one gives rise to the supramundane mind of the base of nothingness and makes it present, because the mind of that realm is extremely clear and sharp.

Moreover, because the mind of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is dull and obtuse, one gives rise to the supramundane mind, which is extremely clear and sharp, and makes it present. This supramundane mind should not take the first and second bases as its support, because those two realms are all mundane, and also because one is born in other realms and gives rise to the minds of other realms and makes them present. It is unreasonable for both supports to be so.
Moreover, this very mind should not take nirvÄá¹‡a as its support, because it has remaining support.
If these three kinds of destinies do not exist, if one does not believe in the existence of the Älaya consciousness, what is the basis of the supramundane mind?
The treatise says:
Moreover, when about to die, creating good or evil, either below or above, the basis gradually cools.
If one does not believe in the existence of the Älaya consciousness, all of this is not possible.
Therefore, if one departs from the consciousness that is the result of the maturation of all seeds, this defiled birth is also not possible.
The commentary says:
When about to give up life, creating good or evil, either below or above, the body gradually cools. Those who create good will definitely ascend, while those who create evil will definitely descend.
If one does not admit that the Älaya consciousness is able to grasp and hold, how can there be a basis for gradual cooling?
Because the Älaya consciousness is able to grasp and hold, either below or above, in accordance with the place that is abandoned, the body then has cold.
The treatise says:
How is mundane purity not established?

Namely, one who has not yet abandoned the craving of the desire realm and has not yet attained the mind of the form realm, uses the wholesome mind of the desire realm to diligently cultivate practices in order to abandon the craving of the desire realm.

This mind of practice in the desire realm and the mind of the form realm do not arise and cease together, therefore it is not perfumed by it. It is not reasonable for it to be the seed of that [form realm mind].
Moreover, the mind of the form realm that has long passed has many other minds in between, it should not be the seed of the present concentrated mind, because it is only nonexistent.

Therefore, the mind of concentration of the form realm, which is the result of the maturation of the consciousness that possesses all the seeds, is transmitted in succession and becomes the present cause, and the wholesome mind of practice is the dominant condition.
In this way, in all the stages of detachment from desire, one should understand accordingly.
In this way, mundane purity, if apart from the consciousness that is the result of maturation and possesses all the seeds, is not logically possible.
The commentary says:
How mundane purity is not logically possible will now be shown.

That is, in order to be free from attachment to the realm of desire, when a wholesome mind of the realm of desire cultivates practices, this wholesome mind of the realm of desire has never been perfumed by a wholesome mind of the realm of form, because they do not arise and cease together, and now the mind of the realm of form should have no seeds that arise by themselves.

Moreover, the wholesome mind of the realm of form in the past is separated by many lifetimes and other consciousnesses, and because it only does not exist and has already passed away, it cannot be the seed for the mind of concentration in the present.
The transmission of causes and conditions in succession is because the Älaya consciousness holds their seeds.
The mind of the realm of form in the present arises from its own seeds, and the wholesome mind of practices is not without efficacy.

As for efficacy, it is only the dominant condition, not the causal condition, because this mind of the realm of form arises through the power of that dominant condition. Being free from attachment to the realm of form, etc., should be understood as appropriate.
The treatise says:
How is supramundane purity not established?
The World-Honored One has said that the arising of right view is due to the causes of the words and teachings of others and the individual's own proper reflection.
Do these words and teachings of others and proper reflection perfume the ear consciousness, or do they perfume the mental consciousness, or do they perfume both?

When one properly contemplates those dharmas, at that time the ear consciousness is not yet able to arise, and the mental consciousness is also interrupted by various other distracted consciousnesses.

If it arises in association with proper reflection, then this mental consciousness perfumed by hearing has long since ceased and definitely does not exist. How can it again be the seed able to give rise to a mind associated with proper reflection at a later time?

Moreover, this mind associated with proper reflection is a worldly mind, and that mind associated with right view is a supramundane mind. There has never been a time when they arose and ceased together. Therefore this mind is not perfumed by that.
Since it is not perfumed, it is unreasonable that it be the seed of that.
Therefore, if supramundane purity were to be apart from the consciousness that is the retribution of the seeds of all dharmas, it would also not be possible.
Because the perfuming of hearing is included in the seeds of that consciousness, and is not associated with it.
The commentary says:
Now, it will be shown how supramundane purity is not possible.
The words of another, proper attention means the attention associated with the words.
The mental consciousness is also interrupted by various distracted consciousnesses means that the supramundane mind associated with right view is interrupted.
When it arises associated with proper attention means at a later time.
This mental consciousness perfumed by hearing is long since extinguished and past, definitely without substance means that after a long time has passed, it is definitely without substance.

How can it again be the seed able to produce a mind associated with proper attention at a later time? This means that it is long since extinguished and presently without substance, and cannot be the cause.
Here, the perfuming of hearing includes the seeds of that [consciousness], but it is not associated with it. This refers to the worldly manas.
As for the perfuming of hearing here, it refers to the perfuming of hearing the correct teaching based on the words of others.
As for including the seeds of that [consciousness], it means that in the manas it includes the seeds of supramundane pure [consciousness].
As for not being associated with it, it means that what they imagine is unreasonable, so how can it be said that this [consciousness] arises from that [manas]?
The treatise states:
Next, how can the consciousness that is the result of retribution with all seeds be the cause of defilement and also be the seed of the supramundane pure mind that can counteract it?
Moreover, since the supramundane mind has never been cultivated before, its perfuming must definitely be absent. If there is no perfuming, from what seeds does it arise?
Therefore, it should be answered:
It arises from the seeds of the perfuming of hearing the correct teaching, which flows from the most pure Dharma realm.
The commentary states:ğŸ”½Here, the perfuming of hearing refers to the perfuming of hearing the correct teaching based on the words of others.
How is it so? It means that the cause of the afflicted is the retribution consciousness, and it is not reasonable for it to be the cause of the antidote.
Also, the supramundane mind that has never been cultivated before means that it has not yet arisen.
The seeds of its perfuming must definitely be nonexistent means that for this reason, the supramundane mind has no perfuming and is definitely without doubt.

Arisen from the seeds of the perfuming of correct hearing that flows from the most pure realm of reality means that in order to show that the realm of reality is different from that of the sravakas, etc.,

it is said to be most pure. Because the realm of reality realized by the World Honored Buddha is eternally severed from the obstacles of afflictions and the knowable, the teachings such as the sutras that flow from the most pure realm of reality are called the outflow of the most pure realm of reality.
Correctly hearing such sutras, etc. is called correct hearing.
The perfuming that arises from this correct hearing is called perfuming.
Or else, correct hearing is itself perfuming, and therefore it is called the perfuming of correct hearing.

This perfuming continues to exist in the store consciousness as a cause that can produce supramundane minds. Therefore it is said to be born of the seeds of the perfuming of hearing that flows from the pure realm of the Dharma.
The Treatise says,
Is this perfuming of hearing by nature the store consciousness or not?
If it is by nature the store consciousness, how can it be the seed of its antidote?
If it is not by nature the store consciousness, what is the basis of this perfuming of hearing?

Until one realizes the enlightenment of Buddhahood, this perfuming of hearing is located in the consciousness that is retribution, in one of its various supports, and evolves together with it in a combined state, like water and milk.
However, it is not the store consciousness, because it is the seed of the antidote to that consciousness.
The Commentary says,
Is this perfuming of hearing by nature the store consciousness or not?
If this is so, what is wrong with that?
If it is the intrinsic nature of the Älaya consciousness, how can it be the seed of the antidote to the Älaya consciousness?
If it is not the intrinsic nature of the Älaya consciousness, then the seeds of this hearing permeation must have a separate support.
Up to the attainment of the enlightenment of the buddhas means up to the attainment of the unsurpassed enlightenment realized by the buddhas.
This hearing permeation is the permeation of hearing that flows out of the most pure dharma realm.
In any one kind of basis of transformation means in any one place of transformation in a continuum.

Residing in the consciousness as retribution and combining with it and evolving together like water and milk means that although the seeds of this hearing permeation are not the same as the consciousness as retribution, they reside in the consciousness and are like water and milk combining and evolving together.
Although they transform as if they were a single nature in combination, they are not the Älaya consciousness, because they are by nature seeds that counteract the Älaya consciousness.
The Treatise says:

Here, based on the weak perfuming, the medium perfuming is achieved; based on the medium perfuming, the strong perfuming is achieved. This is because one attains union through much practice of hearing, thinking, and cultivation.
The Commentary explains:
Here, the weak, medium, and strong are said to be based on the wisdoms of hearing, thinking, and cultivation, because each of these has three levels.
There is another interpretation: The wisdom of hearing is weak, the wisdom of thinking is medium, and the wisdom of cultivation is strong.
Because one attains union through much practice of hearing, thinking, and cultivation, that is, because one practices hearing, etc., repeatedly and with great intensity.
Moreover, here, the weak is the cause for achieving the medium, and the medium is the cause for achieving the strong.
The Treatise says:

It should be known that the seeds of the perfuming of this correct hearing, whether of the lower, middle, or superior varieties, are also seeds of the Dharma body. They are opposed to the Älaya consciousness and are not included in the Älaya consciousness, because they are the nature of the outflow of the most pure realm of the Dharma, which is transmundane.
Although they are mundane, they are the nature of the seeds of the transmundane mind.

Also, although the transmundane mind has not yet been born, it is able to oppose the bonds of the passions, it is able to oppose the difficult and evil destinies, and it is able to destroy the evil actions that have been done. It is able to follow and serve all buddhas and bodhisattvas.

Although it is mundane, it should be known that it is included in the Dharma body of the bodhisattva in the stage of equipment. That obtained by the disciples and solitary enlightened ones is only included in the body of liberation.
Also, this perfuming is not the Älaya consciousness, but is included in the Dharma body and the body of liberation.
As the perfuming of suchness gradually increases in the upper, middle, and lower grades, the consciousness of retribution gradually decreases in the same way, and thus the basis is transformed.
When the basis of all seeds is transformed, the consciousness of retribution and all seeds are transformed without seeds, and all seeds are eternally eliminated.
The commentary says:
Those who are already able to counteract the bonds of afflictions refer to those who are able to eliminate the dominant greed and other manifest [afflictions] and the causes of their transformation.
Those who are already able to counteract the evil destinies refer to those who, if able to eliminate the bonds of afflictions, can thereby counteract the evil destinies.

Those who have already made the antidote to all evil karma that has been done refer to those who, although they have karma that will ripen in the future and should fall into evil destinies, are able to make it the cause for its destruction.
In brief, this hearing-acquired habit energy is able to counteract all evil karma of the past, future, and present.
Also, being able to follow and encounter all Buddhas and Bodhisattvas means being the cause for oneself to encounter good friends in the future.

Although it is worldly, it should be known that the attainment of the bodhisattva who is initially cultivating practices is also included in the Dharma body means that the bodhisattvas who are ordinary beings are called bodhisattvas who are initially cultivating practices. Because they are also the seeds of the Dharma body, it is said that they are also included in the Dharma body.

The attainment of the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas is only included in the liberation body means that the perfuming of the correct hearing of the Å›rÄvakas and so forth is only the cause for liberation, and they only attain the liberation body but not the Dharma body.
The treatise says:
Next, how is it like water and milk?

The non-Älaya consciousness does not coexist with the Älaya consciousness in the same place, yet the seeds of the Älaya consciousness are exhausted and the seeds of the non-Älaya consciousness increase.
It is like a goose drinking milk from water.

Also, when one attains freedom from desire in the world, the perfuming of the non-concentrated stages gradually decreases, while the perfuming of the concentrated stages gradually increases, and one attains the transmutation of the support.
The commentary says:
Although the non-Älaya consciousness and the Älaya consciousness exist together in the same place, when the Älaya consciousness is exhausted, the non-Älaya consciousness remains.
This is shown by the previous simile of the goose drinking the mixture of water and milk, leaving only the water when the milk is exhausted.

Also, when one attains freedom from desire in the world, within a single Älaya consciousness, the perfuming of the afflictions of the non-concentrated stages gradually decreases, while the perfuming of the wholesome dharmas of the concentrated stages gradually increases, and one attains the transmutation of the support. The transmutation of the support here should be understood in the same way.
The treatise says:
Also, when one enters the concentration of cessation, consciousness does not leave the body, as it is said by the sages.
Here, the consciousness that is retribution should be understood as not leaving the body, not because it arises to counteract the concentration of cessation.
The commentary says:
The consciousness that enters and is reborn in the samÄdhi of cessation is not separate from speech, in order to establish that the Älaya consciousness definitely exists.

The World Honored One said that consciousness is not separate from the body, because apart from the consciousness as retribution, the other consciousnesses cannot be established. Because the samÄdhi of cessation arises as an antidote to the evolving consciousnesses, this samÄdhi is considered to be the most tranquil.
The treatise says:
Moreover, this consciousness does not arise again upon leaving the samÄdhi, because once the consciousness as retribution has been interrupted, apart from the bonds of continuity there is no rebirth.
The commentary says:
If one grasps that this consciousness arises again upon leaving the samÄdhi, then by this intention consciousness is not separate from the body.
This is unreasonable, because the consciousness does not arise again upon leaving the samÄdhi.
Once the consciousness as retribution has been interrupted, apart from the bonds of continuity there is no rebirth by relying on another birth.
The treatise says:
Moreover, if there are those who grasp that there is mind in the samÄdhi of cessation because of mental consciousness,

This mind is not established because it is definitely not established, because the object and mode of activity cannot be obtained, because there would be the fault of association with wholesome roots, because unwholesomeness and indeterminate [states] are unreasonable, because there would be the fault of the actual presence of conceptualization and feeling, because contact can be obtained, because there is the function of concentration, because there would be the fault of the mere cessation of conceptualization, because there would be the fault of the actual presence of volition, faith, and other wholesome roots, because it is unreasonable for the supported to be separated from the support by uprooting it, because there is an analogy, and because, like the non-pervasive [mental factors], this [mind] does not exist.
The commentary says:

Moreover, if there is the grasping of mind because of mental consciousness, and this mind is not established, if one wishes to be apart from the previously explained self-characteristic Älaya consciousness, and there is mind in the attainment of cessation because of the other evolving consciousnesses, this is unreasonable.
Why is it so?
Because it is definitely not established, and because mind is never seen apart from mental factors.
Like the other mental factors, conceptualization and feeling would also not cease.
However, this cessation is manifested by the cessation of all mental activities, and therefore it should not be attained.
If you maintain that only the Älaya consciousness exists, then there is no problem.
Those who seek a state of quietude give rise to this samÄdhi in order to counteract the enemies of mental activities, and not in order to counteract the unclear nature of the Älaya consciousness.
Also, there is no other mind in this samÄdhi.
Why is this?
Because the object and mode of activity cannot be apprehended.
The mind and mental activities are in a continuous series and are never separated from their objects and modes of activity.
If there is a mind in this samÄdhi, it also should not be separated from its object and mode of activity.
However, these two are both unobtainable, and therefore there is no other mind in this samÄdhi.
If you maintain that only the Älaya consciousness exists, there is no problem, because it is manifested as the support of the appropriation of a body.
If there were a transforming consciousness in this samÄdhi, it would have to be classified as good, bad, or indeterminate.
But it is not good, because it would have to be associated with the roots of goodness, and that is impossible.
It is not good by its very nature, because it is not good apart from being associated with the roots of goodness, because it is established that the mind of samÄdhi is good.
It is not associated with the roots of goodness such as noncovetousness, because it is not admitted that it is different from other good minds, and this error would occur everywhere.
Also, it cannot be bad or indeterminate, because it is unreasonable that it be bad or indeterminate.
It is not bad, because when one is free from desire, all the roots of badness are eternally cut off. It is not indeterminate, because this samÄdhi is good.
It cannot be established that this mind is good, because it would be in error to have the actual dharmas of thought and its activities.
If the good mind does not exist apart from the roots of goodness, then the roots of goodness must be present.
Just as there is the presence of the roots of goodness in this state, so also conceptualization and feeling must be present, because there is no reason for their absence.
But this is not reasonable, because the antidote to the obstacle cannot be present while the obstacle is present.
For example, when greed and so on are present, the contemplation of impurity is definitely absent.
Also, apart from the store consciousness, no other mind can be present in this samÄdhi, because it is an error to suppose that there is a feeling.

Just as there is no doubt that other samÄdhis are associated with roots of goodness, so also in this samÄdhi, when other consciousnesses are present, there must be contact, because it is born of samÄdhi and has the characteristic of lightness and comfort, whether it is favorable to the feeling of pleasure or to the feeling that is neither pleasurable nor painful.
This contact, as a condition, produces either the feeling of pleasure or the feeling that is neither pleasurable nor painful.
Why is this?
Because this power exists in other samÄdhis.
In the other meditative states, these two contacts are seen to have the ability to produce two feelings. This should also be so here, because there is no reason to obstruct them.
The arising of feeling with contact as its condition should reach here, but it is not reasonable.
Why is this?
Because there would be the fault of only the cessation of conceptualization.
If it is accepted that this contact produces feeling, then in this meditative state only conceptualization should cease.
But it cannot be accepted that conceptualization and feeling both cease, because it is said by the sages.
Moreover, if there is any other consciousness in this meditative state, it must be associated with contact.
This is not reasonable.
Why is this?
Because there would be the fault of the actual presence of volition and the roots of goodness such as faith, if there were contact.

If there is consciousness that evolves associated with contact, there must be volition and so forth that arise together with it, because it is said by the sages. Volition should reach here and be actually present.
If there is the actual performance of volition in this samÄdhi that creates a good mind, there must be the actual performance of the roots of goodness such as faith, but this cannot be accepted.

If one wishes to avoid the various faults mentioned above and the fault of contradicting the Ä€gamas, and because one is only disgusted with mental factors and only removes mental factors, and in this samÄdhi only establishes the existence of mind and not mental factors, this is also unreasonable.
Why is this?
Because it is unreasonable to remove the basis and cause it to be separated from the supported.

The supported is mind, and the supported by mind are mental factors. The supported and the supporting mind and mental factors have never been separated from each other since beginningless birth and death.
Because of this mutual attraction, therefore it must be associated with the roots of goodness such as non-greed.

If it is said that because this samÄdhi and the expedient means for entering samÄdhi are contrary to the roots of goodness such as non-greed, the roots of goodness do not operate in samÄdhi, and only the good mind operates,
this has never been seen anywhere else.
If at the time of the cause, those dharmas are associated, and at the time of the homogeneous cause, there is also association, then it is unreasonable.
It is also unreasonable because there is an analogy.
The World-Honored One said:
The cessation of all bodily actions, the cessation of all verbal actions, and the cessation of all mental actions.
Here, bodily actions refer to inhalation and exhalation. Verbal actions refer to investigation and scrutiny. Mental actions refer to thoughts and so forth.
Just as when investigation and scrutiny cease, speech necessarily does not arise,
so it is with the mind. If mental actions cease, it should also not arise.
If your idea is that just as when bodily actions cease, while in concentration the body remains and does not cease,
so it is with the mind. Although mental actions cease, it should remain and not cease.
This is also unreasonable.
Why is it so?
Because, like non-pervasive dharmas, this does not exist.
As the World-Honored One said:
Apart from bodily actions, there are causes for the body to remain, namely food and drink, the life faculty, consciousness, and so forth.
Therefore, although there is no inhalation or exhalation, the body remains.

The mind is not like this. Apart from the activities of the mind, there is no other cause that can make the mind remain. Therefore, it should reach a state without mental consciousness. It is called the samÄdhi of no mind because the consciousness that is the result of retribution exists in this state.

The World-Honored One said that consciousness is not separate from the body. After this consciousness, which contains all seeds, one emerges from samÄdhi, the evolving consciousnesses are born again. Therefore, one should know that the Älaya consciousness definitely exists.
The treatise says:

Moreover, in this samÄdhi, because of mental consciousness, if one grasps that there is mind, this mind cannot be established as wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate. Therefore, it is unreasonable.
The commentary says:
Having extensively refuted the establishment of the existence of mind in the samÄdhi of cessation, now we will briefly reveal the meaning of the second verse.
If there are those who wish to eliminate the Älaya consciousness and establish the existence of mind in the samÄdhi of cessation because of mental consciousness,
this mind cannot be established as wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate. Therefore, it is unreasonable.
Why is this?

Therefore, this samÄdhi is good by nature, and therefore it is not bad, nor is it indeterminate. Also, the indeterminate activities of deportment, craftsmanship, and transformation do not exist in this samÄdhi.
If you say that this samÄdhi is indeterminate as retribution, then you must admit that it is the Älaya consciousness, because apart from this there is no fifth indeterminate category.

Also, if the mind in this samÄdhi is good, it must be associated with the roots of goodness such as absence of craving, etc. If defiled mind is eliminated and only good mind remains, then at that time, the support of the good mind and its objects exist, and the union of the three must produce contact. Why is it that contact does not arise in this samÄdhi?
If there is contact, why do such mental activities as feeling not arise?
In that case, this samÄdhi of cessation would not be possible, because all minds and mental activities would not cease.

Also, if you insist that this samÄdhi is good, then it must be associated with the roots of goodness such as absence of craving, etc., because it is attracted by a good mind that is a preparatory stage for samÄdhi.
The good mind in samÄdhi is not associated with the roots of goodness such as absence of craving, etc.
Also, when the three factors are capable of producing feeling, they can also produce feeling.
If the three factors are not capable of producing feeling, they only produce contact.
Therefore, even though there is good mind in samÄdhi, it is not associated with the roots of goodness such as non-greed, and there is also no feeling, etc.
This is not so. Since the mind of skillful means is not associated with the roots of goodness such as non-greed, why is the mind of outflow that it produces not so?

Also, it is unreasonable to uproot the dependent and leave the basis. Mind and mental factors have been mutually inseparable since beginningless time. Now, uprooting the dependent and causing it to leave the basis is definitely unobtainable.
Why is this?
Because there is an analogy.

That is to say, in the world from birth to destruction, they are mutually inseparable at all times. It is unreasonable to uproot the dependent and cause it to leave the basis.ğŸ”½It is unreasonable to cause the dependent to leave the basis.
The same is true of mental activities, which cannot be separated from the mind that supports them.
Therefore it is not reasonable to say that in this samÄdhi there are no mental activities but only good mind.

If someone else says that it is unreasonable to say that the support is eliminated and the supported is not, and that feeling and conceptualization are obstacles to this samÄdhi and are eliminated in the preparatory stage of the samÄdhi,
it is not reasonable to say that only these two are not active and the other mental activities are active.
Why is this?
Because the nonuniversal mental activities are absent in this samÄdhi.
The nonuniversal mental activities can be eliminated in this samÄdhi, but the two universal mental activities cannot be eliminated.
If the universals are eliminated, mind is also eliminated, because there is no other cause.
Therefore the socalled mind in this samÄdhi is the result of retribution, and definitely not mental consciousness.
The Treatise says that if there is another opinion that form and mind are the seeds of all dharmas, this is not possible, as was said earlier.
Also, it would not make sense for one to fall from the formless realm or the non-percipient heavens, or to emerge from the attainment of cessation, etc.

The commentary says:

If there is another view that form and mind arise in immediate succession and are the seeds of all dharmas, that is, if there is a view that the form of the previous moment can be the seed, and the form of the subsequent moment arises due to that, and the same is so for the prior and subsequent consciousnesses, etc.,
this has already been refuted.
Also, when form arises again after falling from the formless realm, form has long been extinguished, so how can it be a seed?
When the mind arises again after falling from the non-percipient heavens, or emerging from the attainment of cessation, etc., the mind has long been extinguished, so how can it be a cause of mind?

The preceding moment of form in relation to the subsequent form, and the preceding moment of consciousness in relation to the subsequent consciousness, should be understood as having the condition as cause, but not the condition as immediate antecedent.
The treatise states:
Thus, if one departs from the consciousness that is the ripening of various seeds, both defilement and purification would be impossible.
Therefore, the existence of the Älaya consciousness, which possesses the characteristics explained above, is definitely established.
The commentary states:
Because of the innumerable reasons explained above, the existence of the Älaya consciousness is therefore established.
The treatise states:
Herein, there are three verses:
The bodhisattva, with a pure mind, far removed from the five consciousnesses,
Without any remaining mind, how could you accomplish the transformation of the basis?

If the transformation of the basis is accepted as being without seeds or without substance,
Because there is no duality, the transformation of the basis is not reasonable.
The commentary says:
The transformation of the basis is not accomplished through the transformation of the active consciousnesses, as shown by these three verses.
The bodhisattva in a pure mind means the wholesome manas consciousness associated with the supramundane antidote.
Far removed from the five consciousnesses means it is far removed from the five consciousnesses such as the eye consciousness.
Without remainder means there is no wholesome contaminated manas consciousness.
Having already mentioned the pure mind, it again mentions without remainder in order to exclude wholesome contaminated consciousness.

How is the transformation of the mind accomplished? If you believe in the existence of the Älaya consciousness that can serve as the seeds for all contaminations, the meaning of without seeds is called the transformation of the mind.
If it is not so, how should it be accomplished?
If the arising of the antidote is called the transformation of the basis, this is not reasonable.
Why is it so?
If the transformation of the basis through the antidote is not due to elimination, it cannot be a contamination.
The eternal severing of the obstacle is called the transmutation of the support. The counteragent is not the eternal severing, because it is only the cause of the eternal severing.
If this is so, then there is the error that cause and effect are not distinguished.
The effect is eternal severing, which is called nirvÄá¹‡a, and the cause is the counteragent, which is called the holy path.
If the counteragent is eternal severing, then there is the error that cause and effect are one substance. As soon as the counteragent is generated, it should be nirvÄá¹‡a.

If it is admitted that the transmutation of the support is the absence of seeds or the absence of substance, then if the evolving consciousness is made seedless or is made absent of substance, it is admitted that the transmutation of the support is achieved.
But this is not reasonable, because the absence of those two absences is not the transmutation of the support.
Because the defiled evolving consciousnesses do not exist in this stage of samÄdhi, nor is there any seed that can be made absent.
It is not reasonable to call the absence of the two absences the transmutation of the support.

If the Älaya consciousness definitely exists, then even though the defiled evolving consciousnesses do not exist in this samÄdhi, their seeds must all be present in the Älaya consciousness, and it is possible for them to be without seeds and without substance.
Therefore, the transformation of the support is not reasonable, and you must believe that the Älaya consciousness exists.

This is a brief indication, which will be explained in detail later.

The uncommon characteristics refer to the seeds of the individual internal sense bases.
The common characteristics are the seeds that do not produce results, and the uncommon characteristics are the seeds that produce results.
When the antidotes arise, only the uncommon characteristics that are to be eliminated are extinguished;
The common characteristics are upheld by the discriminations of others and are only seen to be pure.
Just as a yogin, in one thing, has various superior understandings, and what is seen by the true seeds is all established.
Herein, there are two verses:
What is difficult to sever and difficult to thoroughly know should be known as the common bonds,
Because the mind of the yogi is different, due to the greatness of external characteristics.
Although the pure one does not extinguish, he sees purity within it,
And also the pure buddha land is seen as pure by the Buddha.
There is another verse, corresponding to the previously cited, establishing the various understandings and various views.
The yogis, regarding one thing, have various understandings, each different,
And the various views are all established, therefore one knows that the grasped objects only exist as consciousness.
If this were not so, the distinctions in the arising of the vessel world and the sentient world would not be possible.
The commentary says:
Herein, if the Älaya consciousness is the essence of the cause of the common vessel world for all sentient beings, it is the seed of non-experience.
If the Älaya consciousness is the cause of the individual and separate sense bases such as form, etc., then it must contain seeds that are born and perish.

If one were to exclude from the Älaya consciousness this kind of common and shared cause of the receptacle world that is experienced by all sentient beings, then the world as container would not exist.
In the same way, if one were to exclude the second kind of individual cause of the world of sentient beings, then the world of sentient beings would not exist.
In that case, sentient beings would be born as insensate things such as plants.
The Treatise says that the Älaya consciousness has the characteristic of coarseness and the characteristic of calmness.
The characteristic of coarseness is the seeds of the passions and secondary passions.
The characteristic of calmness is the seeds of pure and impure good dharmas.
If this were not so, then the retribution that is received would be without any capacity, and the distinction of the support that has this capacity would not exist.
It also has the characteristic of being exhausted by experience and the characteristic of not being exhausted by experience.
The characteristic of being exhausted by experience is the seeds of good and bad dharmas that have already matured into results.

The characteristic of non-exhaustion refers to the seeds of perfuming by verbal expression, because they are the seeds of the various false discriminations that have been circulating since beginningless time.
If this were not so, then the exhaustion of the results of good and evil actions already done would not be possible.
Also, the arising of new perfuming by verbal expression would not be possible.
There is also the characteristic of analogy, because this Älaya consciousness is analogous to a magical creation, a mirage, a dream, and a visual distortion.
If this were not so, then the characteristic of the inverted conditions would not be possible, because of the seeds of unreal imagination.

There is also the characteristic of completeness and incompleteness, which refers to the characteristic of completeness for those who are bound by all fetters, and the characteristic of diminution for those who are free from worldly desires.

The Älaya consciousness is also like this. Because of the seeds of unreal imagination, there are characteristics that are conditions for error.
